journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Nonlinear, parametrically excited dynamics of two-stage spur gear trains with mesh stiffness fluctuation

article-meta.aff: 3State Key Lab for Mechanical Systems and Vibration, University of Michigan-Shanghai Jiao Tong University Joint Institute, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Robert G Parker, University of Michigan-Shanghai Jiao Tong University Joint Institute, Shanghai, China. Email: parker.242@osu.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: This work studies the nonlinear, parametrically excited dynamics of two spur gear pairs in a two-stage counter-shaft configuration. The dynamic model includes parametric excitations and contact loss of both tooth meshes with two different mesh frequencies. The time-varying mesh stiffnesses and nonlinear tooth separation functions are reformulated into forms suitable for perturbation analysis. The periodic steady-state solutions are obtained by the method of multiple scales and compared against a semi-analytical harmonic balance method as well as numerical integration for fundamental and subharmonic resonances for ranges of system parameters. The interaction of the two meshes is found to depend strongly on the relation of the two mesh periods. The dynamic influences of design parameters, such as shaft stiffness, mesh stiffness variations, contact ratios, and mesh phasing, are discussed. The closed-form solutions provide design guidelines in terms of the system parameters.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Gear vibration and the associated noise and reliability problems are well-known concerns in many industries. The vast majority of gear vibration research addresses single gear pairs, even though most practical systems use multi-mesh, multi-stage gear trains. The two-stage systems studied in this article are in common industry use. Prior gear dynamics research yields a variety of mathematical gear models that are reviewed in Blankenship and Singh,1 Ozguven and Houser2 and Velex and Maatar.3 Three different lumped-parameter models are evaluated against commercial finite element analysis in Liu and Parker.4 A model with time-varying mesh stiffness is used in Liu and Parker5 to analytically study nonlinear idler gear dynamics. Interaction between the two meshes is found to be critical to in such systems. Analytical models with periodically varying mesh stiffnesses for two-stage gear systems are found in Lin and Parker,6 Umezawa et al.7 and Vinayak et al.8 A model with periodic static transmission error excitation is adopted for two-stage helical gear systems in Kahraman.9 Only the mean value of mesh stiffness is considered in the stiffness matrix, and the mesh stiffness variation is implicitly included in the static transmission error. Special commercial finite element gear models combined with contact mechanics have been developed and used successfully on dynamic analysis.10–13

The studies on two-stage gear systems (Figure 1) are much fewer than for single gear pair systems. The complexity of two-stage systems lies not only in the increased number of gear bodies but, more importantly, the interactions between the multiple gear meshes compared to single-stage gear systems. Most published experiment data in the literature are related to single mesh gear pairs. Some are related to planetary gears. Published test data on two-stage gears is very limited. Umezawa et al.7 presented test data showing different coupling effects in low and high speed regimes. Kubur and Kahraman14 compared their linear finite element model to experiments for a three-shaft helical gear system. Most research regarding two-stage gear arrangements are analytical studies. Figure 1.
Rotational model of a two-stage gear system.

Dynamic coupling in two-stage gear systems are studied in Velex and Maatar,3 Vinayak et al.8 and Raclot and Velex,15 where the impact of shaft flexibility between the two middle gears is examined. The work in Iwatsubo et al.16 discusses coupled lateral-torsional vibration of a two-stage gear trains. The analytical solution for linear response is obtained when a multiple of mesh frequency equals a natural frequency. It is concluded that adopting an adequate mesh phase or contact ratio can avoid some resonances. The dynamics of idler and two-stage gearsets is investigated in Umezawa et al.7 Mesh phasing and contact ratio are found to impact gear dynamics for both of these. Dynamic coupling between two meshes in two-stage gears has been identified in the past. Lida et al.17 studied dynamic coupling effect of a two-stage gear train using a linear dynamic model. Contact loss is ignored. Al-shyyab and Kahraman18 investigated nonlinear sub-harmonic responses of two-stage gears using the harmonic balance method. The mesh interaction between two gear meshes is apparent in the response spectrum of each mesh. Walha et al.19 concluded that the complicated dynamic characteristics are primarily caused by the coupling between the periodic mesh stiffness fluctuations and contact loss. Wang and Zhang20 studied coupled dynamic response of a two-stage helical gear train using numerical integration method on a nonlinear lateral-rotational model. Parametric instability analyses to predict large amplitude vibration are discussed in Lin and Parker6 and Tordion and Gauvin.21 The mesh phasing (phase between the fluctuating mesh stiffnesses of the two meshes) and contact ratio interaction are predicted to influence the instability boundary when the ratio of the two mesh frequencies are close to an integer multiple.

The past studies on two-stage gearsets rely primarily on numerical integration. The numerical solutions, however, provide limited physical understanding, and the conclusions are often valid for a certain group of parameters. Furthermore, the interactions between the two gear meshes and how to utilize the interactions for vibration reduction have not been explored. Recently, analytical or semi-analytical methods appeared. The method of multiple scales is applied to study nonlinear dynamics of multi-mesh gear trains.5,22 Closed-form approximations are obtained for primary and secondary resonances. The method of harmonic balance with arc length continuation is useful to find unstable periodic solutions and quasi-periodic solutions.5,18,23 The commercial finite element software Calyx has been used to study gear trains using a near-field analytical contact mechanics treatment mated to far-field finite element analysis.10,11,24,25

In this study, the nonlinear and time-varying analytical model includes key design parameters such as mesh stiffness variation, mesh phasing, contact ratios, and mid-shaft stiffness. The dynamic model is compared to a commercial finite element/contact mechanics code. With appropriate assumptions, the present work obtains analytical approximations for the periodic steady-state solutions. The method of multiple scales yields closed-form expressions that connect the important design parameters to the characteristics of the nonlinear resonances (e.g. bifurcation frequencies and peak amplitude). Based on these expressions, this work discusses the interplay between the two meshes with different mesh periods, mesh stiffness variations, and contact ratios, examining their impact on nonlinear response for fundamental, secondary, and subharmonic resonances. The effects of system parameters on the amplitude and characteristic features of the nonlinear resonances are studied analytically and confirmed with numerical integration, harmonic balance, and commercial finite element solutions. The closed-form expressions provide guidelines for vibration reduction by tuning design parameters.

sec.title: Modeling and methodology
sec.p: A two-stage counter-shaft gearset is shown in Figure 1. The input gear (pinion) meshes with a middle gear coaxially connected with another middle gear that transmits power to the output gear. The two middle gears are either connected by a shaft or made from one part. The mesh frequencies of the two gear meshes are different. The fluctuating stiffnesses of the tooth meshes as contact conditions change lead to parametric excitations, and clearances in the gear meshes create contact loss nonlinearity.

sec.title: Assumptions and nomenclature
sec.p: The number of gear teeth and base radii are z1-4 and r1-4, where gears 1, 2, 3, and 4 are the pinion, the two middle gears, and the output gear, respectively. The model considers only rotational degrees of freedom, which assumes that the bearing stiffnesses are large compared to the mesh stiffnesses. This is system-dependent but represents many realistic systems. This assumption is used in much of the gear dynamics literature. The solutions would change with the addition of translational gear motions, but the developed procedure can be applied. Only gear rotational vibrations Ψ1-4 are considered. Mesh phasing is considered instead of the angular orientation of the gear centers, so the gear centers are aligned; there is no loss of generality because the angular orientation only affects the mesh phasing in a rotational model.

Parametric excitation is introduced by the time-varying mesh stiffness kj(t) (mesh index j=1,2) that includes the flexibility of the gear bodies and teeth. The periodic mesh stiffness is calculated by a commercial finite element/contact mechanics method as adopted in prior studies.10,11,13 The gear teeth separate (i.e. contact loss) when the mesh deflection is negative due to backlash. Backside tooth contact is not included because it is rare for systems with proper gear load and backlash. Gear tooth profile deviations are not included in this study. Constant external torques Q1-4 are applied to each gear with Q2=Q3=0, in general. kr is the torsional stiffness of the middle shaft. Torsional stiffnesses of the input and output shafts are not considered, but they can be included if appropriate. To remove the rigid body mode, elastic motions are introduced as (1) where x1,2 are dynamic transmission errors (DTE) and x3 is the relative motion between the two middle gears.

sec.title: Mathematical model
sec.p: A three-DOF nonlinear dynamic model is derived in terms of the elastic motions as (2) (3) where K is the stiffness matrix with contact loss nonlinearity and mesh stiffness parametric excitations; the tooth separation functions are E=Q1/r1 is the steady mesh force of the first mesh; and, the mesh frequency ω~j denotes the passing frequency of the gear teeth for mesh j. The two mesh frequencies satisfy ρ=ω~2/ω~1=z3/z2.

Letting k¯j and K¯ be the mean values of kj and K, the eigenvalue problem of equation (2) is (K¯-λ2M)2v=20. The modal matrix V=[v1:v2:v3] is normalized such that VTMV=I. The mean static transmission errors are x¯1=E/k¯1 and x¯2=Er2/(r3k¯2).

Let Γj (j=1,2) be the peak-peak amplitudes of the mesh stiffnesses. The dimensionless mesh stiffness variations are ɛj=Γj/k¯j. According to prior studies,6,26 ɛj<0.5 and these ɛj are the small perturbation parameters. The validity of this choice is shown later in comparisons to numerical integration.
The periodic mesh stiffnesses kj(t) are expanded as (4) where ɛ=ɛ1, ξ=ɛ2/ɛ1=O(1), κ1m=κ~1m/Γ1=O(1), κ2m=κ~2m/Γ2=O(1), and c.c. denotes the complex conjugate of previous terms.

A phase relation exists between the same reference contact state for the two mesh stiffnesses of a two-stage gearset. Without loss of generality, consider two rectangular-wave mesh stiffness approximations as in Figure 2. k1 changes from high to low at the end of mesh period T1. k2 changes from high to low at an instant φT2/(2π) before the end of mesh period T2, where φ is the mesh phasing. According to Parker and Lin,27 the mesh phasing can be designed by changing the gear positions (centerline angles) and gear parameters such as base pitch, pressure angle, outer-diameter, and tooth thickness. It can also be calculated once these are chosen. Because one can achieve any desired mesh phasing even when the gear centers all lie on a straight line, there is no loss in generality in choosing this geometry. Taking the k1 curve to be fixed, the k2 curve can move along x axis by changing φ, i.e. k2 can have a different phase relation to k1. The selection of the reference condition (i.e. the distinguishing feature of each stiffness variation, such as the change from high to low stiffness) does not affect the phase. Figure 2.
Mesh phasing of two rectangular-wave mesh stiffnesses of a two-stage gear system.

The following analysis is for arbitrary mesh stiffness variations represented by Fourier series. The stiffness variations can be measured, calculated by finite element or similar analysis, or assumed to have a particular shape (e.g. trapezoidal or rectangular waves). The complex Fourier coefficients of the mesh stiffnesses in Figure 2 and equation (4) are (5)

The total phase difference between the Fourier coefficients κ~1m and κ~2m includes the stiffness shape difference (as captured by the contact ratio) and the time difference for the same contact state (i.e. the mesh phasing).

Gear resonance with nearly harmonic response10,11,13,28–30 occurs when a mesh frequency or integer multiple of mesh frequency is close to a natural frequency or a particular multiple of natural frequency. The large amplitude response due to parametric instability causes nonlinear contact loss that bounds the vibration. In practice and from numerical integration simulations for most parametric resonances, one contact loss occurs in each periodic response cycle at the response frequency Ω~. This also occurs in commercial finite element simulations. The tooth separation functions Hj are rectangular waves in a cycle. Hj=0 during the separation time intervals qj and Hj=1 for the rest of the response period. (qj/T~=2πΩ~). In addition, numerical simulations show that the time of any tooth separation is small compared to the mesh period. Consequently (6) where Hj=O(1). The tooth separation angles are defined as θj=(q j/T~)π=qjΩ~/2 (θj/π<1).
Two quantities are chosen to non-dimensionalize the equations: the first natural frequency λ1 and the first mesh average static transmission error x¯1. The dimensionless quantities are (7)

The dimensionless governing equations in modal form (with the transformation 2y=V2u) are (8) (9) where μ=2ζ/ɛ captures the small modal damping ζ and Fd is the component of VT2E. The functions fdp include the mesh stiffness parametric excitations and nonlinear tooth separation of the two meshes. Gear systems are lightly damped for efficient power transmission. In this case, a modal damping approximation is reasonable. Comparisons of a modal damping model and gear vibration experiments show modal damping values of 1–5%.31,32 This study uses 3%.

sec.title: Method of multiple scales
sec.p: The method of multiple scales33 is adopted to seek approximate analytical solutions for equation (8). The unknown dynamic responses ud are approximated by asymptotic power series in ɛ, and τ is expanded into the multiple time scales τn=ɛnτ. The ɛ0 and ɛ1 order differential equations (where Dn=∂/∂τn) are (10) (11)

sec.title: Frequency response for fundamental resonances
sec.p: Case 1: ωa≈cs, and ρ≠z or 1/z (z is an integer)
In this case, one of the two mesh frequencies is near the sth natural frequency. From equation (10), the leading order solutions for Ω=ωa=cs+ɛσ (σ is the detuning) are (12)

Fs is the constant term capturing the response to the steady applied external torque, and its influence on the nonlinear response is included in all calculations that follow. To avoid simultaneous parametric or internal resonances c2≠2c1, c3≠2c2, and c3≠2c1.
Using similar procedure as Liu and Parker5 (and see the Appendix 2), the perturbation solution for the frequency response is (13) (14)

The phase of the response is γ=μcs 2α(R1α+R2-2csασ)-1-Θ. R1,2 are functions of the separation functions θj and determine the backbone curves of the softening nonlinearity solution branches. The solution branches with θj=0 (i.e. R1,2=0) have no contact loss and represent linear, parametrically excited response. Nonlinear solutions emerge when tooth separation starts and one of the θj≠0.

The steady-state solutions are the equilibria of the solvability conditions equation (40). Their stabilities are determined by the eigenvalues χ of equation (40) linearized about the equilibria. The eigenvalues satisfy (15) where Λ is a continuous function of α and σ whose projection on the α-σ plane is the frequency response function. The solutions are unstable for Λ<0, i.e. there exists a Re(χ) > 0, and stable for Λ>0. Thus, the roots of Λ are bifurcation points, and one can prove that these roots are the points of the frequency response curve with vertical tangents in the α-σ plane (dσ/dα=0). Accordingly, Λ<0 (unstable) between the two tangent points, and Λ>0 (stable) otherwise. This results in jump or hysteresis phenomena at the bifurcation points.

The initiation of contact loss is indicated by yj=0 in equation (36), from which the amplitude αj (CL) at which contact loss occurs at mesh j is computed. This yields αj (CL)=|∑p=1 3vjpFp/2vjs| j = 1,2. The corresponding mesh frequencies are given by equation (13) with α=αj (CL). Thus, for the resonance ωa≈cs (16)
The peak resonant amplitude occurs when the square root term in equation (13) vanishes, i.e. (17) (18)

From the known shape of the classical softening nonlinearity at fundamental resonance, one can closely approximate the frequency response curve from the three points in equations (16) to (18). All quantities in equations (16) and (17) are known explicitly because R3 depends on mesh stiffness variations and vibration modes. This makes them useful for design purposes.

For ρ≠z or 1/z, the peak amplitude and contact loss initiation frequencies depend only on the mesh stiffness variation of the mesh driving the resonance (mesh a). The other mesh stiffness excitation does not affect these features. This does not mean, however, that the system can be studied by two single mesh gear pairs. First, the dynamic transmission error of the mesh not driving the resonance is strongly excited by the resonant mesh a according to equation (36). Secondly, the mean and amplitude of the dynamic transmission error of mesh a in equation (36) are affected by vibration modes that are not captured in the single mesh pair systems. Finally, the important backbone curves of the softening nonlinearity solution branches determined by R1,2 in equation (14) include tooth separations from both meshes.

When ωa=cs+ɛσ, the other mesh frequency satisfies ωl=ωa/z or ωl=zωa. The perturbation solutions from a procedure similar to that above are given by (13) with (19) where R1,2 are given in equation (14) and ωl=2ωa is considered later. The peak resonant amplitude and mesh frequencies at which contact loss starts are still given by equations (17) and (16).

From equation (19), mesh interaction as captured in the important quantity |R3| occurs if the non-resonant mesh frequency ωl satisfies ωl=ωa/z. The first harmonic of mesh a and the zth harmonic of the other (lth) mesh jointly drive the resonance; this alters the resonance peak shape, peak amplitude, and contact loss initiation frequencies through |R3|. The two terms in |R3| for this case give the separate contributions from mesh a and mesh l excitations. Depending on the contact ratios and mesh phasing between the complex-valued κ~a1 and κ~lz as well as the vibration modes, these two mesh excitations can counteract (reduce amplitude) or reinforce (increase amplitude) each other to affect |R3|. The coefficient weighting of these two terms is impacted heavily by the modal deflections of the two meshes. Although it is typical that |κ~a1|>|κ~lz|, the influence from the non-resonant mesh can be significant for resonance in modes where mesh l dominates.

sec.title: Frequency response for subharmonic resonances
sec.p: When ωa=2cs+ɛσ, subharmonic resonance with dominant response frequency Ω=ωa/2≈cs is excited. The amplitude–frequency relationship for these period -2Ta solutions are (20)

From equation (20), the two frequencies ωa=2cs± |R4|2-4ζ2cs 4/cs for no contact loss (θ1=θ2=R1=R2=0) are the boundaries of primary parametric instability; they can be calculated from linear system analysis that predicts theoretically unbounded period-2Ta response for mesh frequencies in this interval.5,6 Equation (20), however, gives the bounded nonlinear amplitude in this region as a result of contact loss. A discontinuous jump in amplitude occurs at the boundaries of this mesh frequency interval. The instability interval 2|R4|2-4ζ2cs 4/cs depends on the mesh stiffness variation of mesh a, the vibration modes and damping; note that it is independent of the torque, so high loads do not reduce the mesh frequency range where large amplitude response occurs. Unlike for fundamental resonance, the two nonlinear solution branches do not converge to a peak at this order of perturbation (which would occur if the square root in equation (20) vanished).

When ωa=2cs+ɛσ, the other mesh frequency satisfies ωl=ωa/z or ωl=zωa. The frequency response solutions are given by equation (20) with (21) where even z in the first of equation (21) and z=2 in the second are discussed later. For ωl=zωa (z>2), there is no interaction from the non-resonant mesh. For ωl=ωa/z the two meshes interact for subharmonic resonance. The first harmonic of mesh a and the zth harmonic of the other (lth) mesh jointly drive the resonance, and the two terms in R4 indicate the strength of contribution from these two resonant sources. By their influence on κ~a1 and κ~lz, the contact ratios and mesh phasing significantly affect if these sources counteract or reinforce each other. The coefficient weightings have different character than for fundamental resonance in equation (19). The fundamental resonance coefficients all depend on applied torque through Fp, but the subharmonic resonance contributions in equation (21) from both meshes are independent of torque.

sec.title: Frequency response for combined fundamental and subharmonic resonances
sec.p: An important case omitted in preceding results is that of combined fundamental and subharmonic resonance excitation of the same mode. For zωa≈cs and ωl≈2cs (giving ωl=2zωa), mesh l parametrically excites a subharmonic resonance of the sth mode while the zth harmonic of mesh a simultaneously excites fundamental resonance of the same mode. The frequency response relations are (22)

The separate contributions to the important quantity R5 of equation (22) can be identified: the zth harmonic of mesh a drives fundamental resonance (first term in R5), while the (2z)th harmonic of mesh a (second term) and the first harmonic of mesh l (third term) jointly drive subharmonic resonance. In contrast to prior results R5 depends on α because of the combined effects. For linear (no contact loss) response with small amplitude (α < 1) (that is, as the mesh frequencies enter the resonant zone from above or below), the fundamental resonance component dominates the solution. Compared to the discontinuous jump in amplitude near subharmonic resonance from equations (20) and (21), the response amplitude in equation (22) increases sharply but continuously until the large amplitude leads to tooth separation and nonlinear solution. The high amplitude (α > 1) nonlinear solutions are dominated by the subharmonic component and R5≈vas 2κ~a(2z)/k¯a+vls 2κ~l1/k¯l, similar to equation (21). Thus, the two nonlinear solution branches do not converge to a peak at this order of perturbation. The contact loss initiation amplitude is the same as in equation (16), but the associated mesh frequencies ωa (CL) are calculated from equation (22).

sec.title: Harmonic balance method with arc-length continuation
sec.p: To provide numerical comparisons for the perturbation solutions, the harmonic balance method combined with arc-length continuation is used to identify complete solution branches near the nonlinear resonances. This method is applicable to weak and strong nonlinearities, although it can experience numerical convergence problems.

The common period T of the two mesh excitations is an integer multiple of the two mesh periods, according to T=z2T1=z3T2 because of ρ=T2/T1=z2/z3. For period-pT (p is an integer) response, the minimum frequency Ωmin=2π/T satisfies pΩmin=ω1/z2=ω2/z3. The response period is pz2 times the first mesh period and pz3 times the second mesh period.

The periodic solutions are expanded in Fourier series and the sinusoidal functions are discretized by N points in T. The unknown vector U=[us~] contains the Fourier coefficients of the yd (d=1,2,3) which are periodic with frequency Ωmin. The number of harmonics retained in 2U should be no less than max(z2,z3).

Following Liu and Parker5 G is the discrete Fourier series transformation matrix; L is the right inverse of G; M, C, and 2f are the discrete Fourier expansions of mass, damping matrix, and load vector; and K~ is the discretization of the nonlinear, time-varying mesh stiffness matrix. The dimensionless governing equation is formulated into an algebraic equation ready for Newton–Raphson iteration as (23)

Hyperbolic tangent functions [1+tanh(yj)]/2 are used as smooth approximations of the tooth separation functions Hj. The mesh stiffnesses k1,2 are expanded by Fourier series with period pT and discretized into N-dimensional vectors κ1,2 with elements (24) where aj,m and bj,m are known Fourier coefficients.

To follow periodic solution branches as Ωmin varies, the continuation method expands the unknown vector to be 2a={2UTΩmin}T. The Newton–Raphson iteration is (25) where . indicates element-by-element division; 〈•,•〉 is the inner product; J denotes the Jacobian matrix of the residual ℜ in (23); J-1 is the pseudo-inverse; and, superscript p and subscript q are the frequency and iteration number. The iteration reaches the steady-state periodic solution when ‖2aq+1 p-2aq p‖ is less than a specified tolerance.

The continuation method is applied to get the first guess (initial conditions) of the next iteration. The first guess of a new solution along the equilibrium path is 2a0 p+1=2ap+d2s (ds is an arc length). The direction of the arc length is along the tangent plane of the current solution.

sec.title: Evaluation of the mathematical model against commerical finite element
sec.p:
An example two-stage system from an automotive transmission is listed in Table 1. A finite element model is built for this gearset using the commercial software Calyx24 to compare with the analytical model. The analytical foundation for Calyx is presented in Parker et al.,11 and its features for gear dynamics are discussed in Parker et al.10,11 and Vijayakar.25 It is applied in Parker et al.11 where dynamic analyses matched well with single gear pair experiments.28 The shaft connecting the middle gears is assumed rigid. The mesh stiffness variations used in the analytical model are obtained from static analysis of the finite element model at several points of a mesh cycle. Root-mean-square (RMS) values of dynamic transmission error are shown in Figure 3 (in all results the mean values are subtracted prior to computing the RMS). The RMS of steady-state dynamic transmission error representing the frequency response function agrees well with the analytical model solved by numerical integration. Nonlinear jump phenomena from contact loss are evident in the second mode resonances. Different stiffness parameters are used in the following analysis where, based on the good agreement in Figure 3 and other simulations, the comparisons are between perturbation and numerical solutions of the analytical model. Figure 3.
Comparisons of RMS dynamic transmission errors between the analytical (numerical integration) and finite element models for the two-stage gear system in Table 1 and decreasing mesh frequency. — commercial FE dynamic transmission error of the first mesh; – – Analytical dynamic transmission error of the first mesh; – – – commercial FE dynamic transmission error of the second mesh; – – Analytical dynamic transmission error of the second mesh).
RMS: root mean square; FE: finite element. Table 1.
Parameters of the example two-stage gearset for finite element model comparison.
Pinion Middle 1 Middle 2 Output
Number of teeth 51 72 19 73
Module (mm) 1.405 1.405 2.2175 2.2175
Facewidth (mm) 22.5 29 20 20
Moment of inertia (kg m2) 0.01837 0.03531 0.00071 0.1740
Torque (Nm) 100 0 0 -258.4
Contact ratio 1.60 1.70
Mean mesh stiffness (N/m) 4.24×109 3.45×109
Mesh phasing, φ 0.257

sec.title: Comparisons of analytical and numerical solutions
sec.p: The second example two-stage system chosen for the analytical studies uses rectangular mesh stiffnesses in (5) defined by k¯j, ɛj, ςj, and φ. Based on previous FE simulations on mesh stiffness,4,10 the mesh stiffness in the example is simplified as a rectangular wave function, ignoring corner contact and higher order variations. Because it relies only on Fourier expansion of a periodic mesh stiffness, however, the approach in this article applies to general measured or numerically calculated mesh stiffnesses. The default system parameters are kr=6.35×105 N-m/rad, k¯1=2.98×108 N/m, η=1.08, ɛ1,2=0.3, ς1=ς2=1.5, φ=0, ρ=3/5, and ζ=0.03. The middle shaft is no longer rigid. The inertia parameters are the same as Table 1. The dimensionless natural frequencies cs are 1, 2.34, and 3.29. The three modes have their dominant strain energies in y3 (middle shaft), y2 (mesh 2), and y1 (mesh 1), respectively. The frequency response is analyzed by perturbation, harmonic balance, and numerical integration methods.

sec.title: Comparisons of frequency response for ρ=3/5
sec.p:
The RMS of y1 calculated by the three methods are compared in Figure 4(a) where softening nonlinearity and jump phenomena are evident for ω1≈c3. Numerical integration and harmonic balance agree nearly exactly (as they do for all cases in this study). Perturbation agrees with these with meaningful differences for ω1≈1.7. From equation (17) and R3 in equation (14), the resonance at mode 3 (ω3≈3.29) where mesh 1 dominates, i.e. v13 is large, is strongly excited by mesh 1. The subharmonic resonance for ω1≈2c3=6.58 is strongly excited for the same reason. The comparison of perturbation and numerical methods at ω2≈c1=1 (i.e. ω1≈1.7) is poor because y1 has low response in mode 1 (y3 dominates the mode) so the one-mode approximation in equation (36) is not sufficient. Figure 4.
Comparison of RMS of the first mesh dynamic transmission error for ρ = 3/5 and other parameters with default values of the second example system. The mean value component is filtered out. (a) frequency response (— stable perturbation; -------- unstable perturbation; – – – harmonic balance; -o- numerical integration); (b) Spectra of first mesh DTE (- - - ω1=2.90; — ω1=3.53; ---------- ω1=5.86).
RMS: root mean square; DTE: dynamic transmission errors.

For fundamental resonance (period-T), the response period is a common multiple of the two mesh periods, according to T=z2T1=z3T2. Thus, given ρ = 3/5 the minimum response frequencies for ω1=2.90 and ω1=3.53 (near the resonance ω1≈c3=3.29) are ω1/5 in Figure 4(b) as captured by numerical integration. If z2 and z3 have no common factors, the minimum frequency is the shaft frequency. For subharmonic resonance, the response period is twice (period -2T) the common multiple of the two mesh periods. Thus, the minimum frequency for ω1=5.86≈2c3=5.58 is ω1/10 as shown in Figure 4(b).

At subharmonic resonance, the harmonic balance method gives nearly identical solutions as perturbation for the two vertical linear branches delineating the linear system parametric instability boundaries, but it indicates the presence of a resonance peak, a bifurcation point where the stable upper branch and unstable lower branch meet. Numerical integration shows jump-down phenomenon at the peak. The perturbation solution branches, however, do not converge to a resonance peak in a first order perturbation. Similar dual-jumping phenomenon is observed by Bahk and Parker22 for the subharmonic resonance of a planetary gearset.

Although the analytical expression equation (20) cannot directly predict the subharmonic resonance peak amplitude, this amplitude correlates closely with the instability interval width predicted in equation (20). Figure 5 shows the correlation between the instability interval width and peak amplitude for the subharmonic resonance ω1≈2c3 and changing contact ratio, mesh stiffness variation, and modal damping. As computed using harmonic balance, the instability interval and peak amplitude have a linear relationship for changing contact ratio and mesh stiffness variation and a slightly parabolic relation for changing modal damping. The peak amplitude and instability width decrease with increasing contact ratio, increasing modal damping, and decreasing mesh stiffness variation, respectively. Thus, the instability interval width is a proxy for peak amplitude and can be used as a design quantity to minimize vibration. The subharmonic resonance disappears at critical points (e.g. ɛ=0.225). The distance between two adjacent data points increases when approaching the critical points, i.e. the peak amplitude and instability interval become more sensitive to the three parameters. Figure 5.
Correlation of peak amplitude and instability interval width for subharmonic resonance with ω1=2c3, ρ=3/5 and other parameters having default values of the second example system except for: □ 0.027≤ζ≤0.036, * 0.225≤ɛ≤0.350, O 1.50≤ς1≤1.75.

Figure 6 shows the comparison of y2 RMS by the three methods. The fundamental resonance of ω2≈c2 (near ω1≈c2/ρ=3.9) dominates in y2 because |v22|>|v21|. The perturbation solution agrees well with numerical results at this resonance. The other two nonlinear resonances (ω1≈c3=3.29 and ω1≈2c3=6.58) are the fundamental and subharmonic resonances of mode 3 excited by mesh 1. From equation (36), both y1 and y2 respond to mode 3 with amplitude of y1 greater than that of y2 (because |v13|>|v23|). On the other hand, only y2 responds to mode 2 at the resonance ω2≈c2 in Figure 4(a) because v21≈0. Figure 6.
Comparison of RMS of the second mesh dynamic transmission error for ρ = 3/5 and other parameters with default values of the second example system; (— stable perturbation; -------- unstable perturbation; – – – harmonic balance; -O- numerical integration).
RMS: root mean square.

Figure 7 shows the good comparison of y1 RMS for the perturbation and numerical integration solutions. Nonlinear fundamental and subharmonic resonances occur for ω1≈c3=3.29 and ω1≈2c3=6.58, respectively. The fundamental resonance ω1≈c3=3.29 is excited by the first harmonic (κ~11) of mesh 1 and the second harmonic (κ~22) of mesh 2. There is a combination of subharmonic (κ~11 and κ~22) and fundamental (κ~21) resonances at ω1≈2c3=6.58. The perturbation prediction of the nearly vertical linear response solution branches (dominated by the fundamental resonance component in the first term in R5 in equation (22)) and instability interval (defined by the two points where the linear branches change to nonlinear branches) agrees well with numerical integration. As discussed in equation (22), the linear solution branches are not vertical lines (as in Figures 4 and 6) because of the fundamental resonance contribution from mesh 2. No jump down phenomenon occurs for increasing frequency sweeps in this case. The nonlinear solution branches from perturbation are still open at the first order, and the resonant amplitude correlates with the instability interval, similar to the discussion of Figures 4 and 5. Figure 7.
Comparison of RMS of the first mesh DTE for ρ = 1/2 and other parameters with default values of the second example system (— stable perturbation; - - - unstable perturbation; O numerical integration sweep down; • numerical integration sweep up).
RMS: root mean square; DTE: dynamic transmission errors.

sec.title: Dynamic influences of key design parameters
Impact of coupling shaft stiffness on vibration modes
sec.p:
The shaft stiffness between the two middle gears does not appear explicitly in the closed-form perturbation expressions. According to equation (3), however, the shaft stiffness affects the vibration modes that appear explicitly in the perturbation solutions. Figure 8 shows the sensitivity of vibration modes to the shaft stiffness for the example two-stage gear system in Table 1. The shaft stiffness significantly impacts the vibration modes. The shaft stiffness 1×106 N-m/rad separates two limiting cases. For shaft stiffness much lower than this value, the three modes have decoupled y3, y2, and y1. For shaft stiffness higher than 1×106 N-m/rad, the modes change to two coupled modes with both mesh deflections participating and a shaft mode with only relative rotation between the middle gears. For shaft stiffness near 1×106 N-m/rad, coupled mesh deflections and shaft rotations occur in all three modes. Thus, by tuning the shaft stiffness, one can change the modal properties to adjust the resonant response in favorable ways. For instance, the shaft stiffness can affect vas/vls to increase or decrease the mesh interaction in R5 from equation (22). Figure 8.
Sensitivity of vibration modes to stiffness of the middle shaft for the system in Table 1, O λ1, -•- λ2, and * λ3. The bar charts indicate the vibration modes.

The prior response derivations show the need to include all system degrees of freedom and multiple modes regardless of whether the modes are coupled or highly uncoupled between the different degrees of freedom. This is because the excitations arise simultaneously from both meshes, so even decoupled modes where the mesh deformation is concentrated in only one of the two meshes will be excited. This is evident in R4 in (21) and R5 in (22) where multiple modes contribute.

sec.title: Tooth separation
sec.p:
From equations (16) and (17), nonlinear solutions (i.e. contact loss) occur when the peak amplitude is greater than the contact loss initiation amplitude αj (CL). For the resonance ω1≈c3, only the first mesh loses contact as depicted in Figure 9(a) because α1 (CL)<α(P)<α2 (CL); the peak amplitude is less than the initiation amplitude of the second mesh, and contact loss is not activated for the second mesh. The frequency of contact loss is the resonant frequency ω1, which is consistent with the tooth separation frequency in perturbation. For the resonance ω2≈c2, α2 (CL)<α(P)<α1 (CL), which implies that only the second mesh loses contact as shown in Figure 9(b). The frequency of contact loss is the resonant frequency ω2. The mesh forces are periodic with the same period as the response period (T=3T1=5T2). This implies that there are harmonics of ω1/5 or ω2/3 in the response spectra with the dominant amplitude at the resonance frequency. Figure 9.
Steady-state mesh forces at fundamental resonances from numerical integration for default system parameters with response period 5T1=3T2 (— first mesh; – – second mesh); (a) resonance at ω1=3.2≈c3; (b) resonance at ω2=2.34≈c2.

sec.title: Impact of mesh stiffness variations on peak resonant amplitude
sec.p: The rectangular mesh stiffnesses in the second example system are defined by the analytical quantities of mean k¯j, variations ɛj, contact ratios ςj, and mesh phasing φ. The impact of these quantities on the resonance peak are seen by combining equations (5), (14), and (19) to (22) as (26) (27) (28) where wa=∑p=1 3(vapFp), wl=∑p=1 3(vlpFp), φ1=0, φ2=φ, ωa≈cs in (26), ωa≈2cs in (27) and (28). |R5| measures the width of the subharmonic resonance instability interval, which correlates directly with peak amplitude; it is evaluated for α=αa (CL). The 2z harmonic is neglected in equation (28) because its amplitude is small compared to the first harmonic. The peak amplitudes of the respective resonances are determined by |R3|/(2ζcs), |R4|2-4ζ2cs 4/cs, and (indirectly) |R5|b 2-4ζ2cs 4/cs. For the first cases in (26), (27) and (28), the products and summations of both mesh stiffness excitations weighted by the vibration modes. Only one mesh stiffness excitation appears in the second case in (26) and (27).

Figure 10 examines the impact of the mesh stiffness variations ɛ1,2 on the peak amplitude of y2 at the fundamental resonance ω2≈c2 for the second example system by numerical integration. Consistent with the perturbation solution in case 2 of (26), the peak amplitude depends linearly on ɛ2 and is not affected by ɛ1 for ρ=3/5 (Figure 10(a)). In other words, there is no mesh interaction when ρ is not an integer or its reciprocal. The lack of mesh interaction is not due to the mode shape; the stiffness of the middle shaft is 640e3 so the mode shapes are not decoupled (Figure 8). Without mesh interaction, mode 2 (mesh 2 dominates) is purely excited by the mesh stiffness of mesh 2. Due to the mode shape, mesh 1 response also involves mode 2 resonant response. Figure 10(b) shows the sensitivity of the peak amplitude to ɛ1,2 for ρ=1/2. It again matches the analytical form in case 1 of equation (26). Two parametric excitations interact to affect the dynamic response. In this case, controlling only one excitation will not necessarily yield better response. From equation (28) (combined fundamental and subharmonic resonance), the first harmonics of both mesh stiffnesses contribute to the resonance. For the example system, the second mesh deflection dominates mode 2, i.e. |v12|<|v22|. With ς1=1.7, ς2=1.6, and φ=π, equation (28) simplifies to (29) Figure 10.
Impact of two mesh stiffness variations on the amplitude of the fundamental resonance from numerical integration for ω2=3.5≈c2, ς1 = 1.7, ς2 = 1.6, ζ = 3%, and φ = π; (a) ρ = 3/5; (b) ρ = 1/2.

The peak amplitude increases with ɛ1 and ɛ2 but is more sensitive to ɛ2 than ɛ1, consistent with numerical integration (Figure 10(b)). A similar discussion applies to the fundamental resonance (ω1≈c3) that is dominated by the first mesh deflection. The first harmonic of mesh 1 and the second harmonic of mesh 2 contribute to excite the resonance. The peak amplitude is more sensitive to ɛ1 than ɛ2 for case 1 of equation (26). From case 1 of equation (26), smaller z generally yields stronger mesh interactions and higher responses.

The method of multiple scales in case 2 of equation (27) indicates the amplitude of the subharmonic resonance ω1≈c3 with ρ=3/5 correlates to |R4|2-4ζ2cs 4/cs. The presence of subharmonic requires |R4|≥2ζcs 2, which gives (30)

Figure 11(a) shows the peak from numerical integration drops sharply to zero when ɛ1<0.25, as predicted by (30). Without mesh interaction, mode 3 (mesh 1 dominates) is only excited by the mesh stiffness of mesh 1. The response amplitude depends almost linearly on ɛ1 for ɛ1≥0.25. The analytical expression and numerical solution both indicate typical jump phenomenon around ɛ1=0.25. For the same subharmonic resonance with ρ=1/2, the amplitude is affected by both ɛ1 and ɛ2 but more sensitive to ɛ1 (Figure 11(b)). The perturbation solution is from (28) with z=1. For ɛ2=0.2, the condition |R5|≥2ζcs 2 predicts subharmonic resonance when ɛ1≥0.225 (decreases from 0.246 due to the impact of ɛ2). For ɛ1=0.2, the resonance is present when ɛ2≥0.26. Two mesh contributions could be added together or cancel each other depending on the mesh phasing. The constructive or destructive effects in equation (27), however, do not depend on the sign of the vibration modes, unlike the fundamental resonance. Figure 11.
Impact of two mesh stiffness variations on the amplitude of the subharmonic resonance from numerical integration for ω1=2.9≈c3, ς1 = 1.7, ς2 = 1.6, ζ = 3%, and φ = π; (a) ρ = 3/5; (b) ρ = 1/2.

sec.title: Impact of contact ratios on resonant peak amplitude
sec.p:
From equations (26) and (27), the contact ratios contribute to the amplitude and phase of the mesh stiffness harmonics. In case 2 (ωl=zωa,z>2 or ρ≠z,1/z) of equations (26) and (27), the amplitude of resonance (ωa≈cs or 2cs) varies with the contact ratio of mesh a in sinusoidal forms, and the amplitude is independent of the contact ratio of the other mesh. On the other hand, the two contact ratios both contribute to the response in case 1. As an example of case 1 of equation (26), the amplitude of the resonance (ω1≈c3, ρ=1/2) varying with two contact ratios is shown in Figure 12. With ɛ1=ɛ2=0.3 and φ=π, case 1 of equation (26) simplifies to (31) Figure 12.
Impact of two contact ratios on the amplitude of the fundamental resonance from numerical integration for ω1=2.9≈c3, ρ = 1/2, ɛ1=ɛ2 = 0.3, ζ = 3%, and φ = π.

The amplitude is affected by both contact ratios but is more sensitive to ς1 than ς2. The numerical amplitudes change in Figure 12 with ς1 in a similar way as sin2(πς1) variation as predicted. It is, however, not an exact sinusoidal form due to the other modes, higher harmonics, and the modulation by the impact of ς2 in (31). For ς1=1 or 2, |R3|2=0.04sin2(2πς2); the amplitude in Figure 12 shows sin2(2πς2) waveforms with maxima at ς2=1.25 and 1.75 and minima at ς2=1 and 2. For ς1=1.2, (32)
The amplitude has similar waveform but with maxima at ς2=1.1 and 1.6 and minima at 1.35 and 1.85. The peaks and valleys of the wave in Figure 12 shift with ς1 as predicted.

sec.title: Impact of mesh phasing on resonant peak amplitude
sec.p:
One key parameter reflecting the interaction of multi-meshes is mesh phasing, which can change the interaction between the two meshes. In two limiting cases (33) where the two mesh contributions add together or cancel each other. Optimizing the mesh phasing for one mode, however, might significantly increase the resonant amplitude at another mode having different signs of the modal deflections. For the first two cases in equations (26) and (27), mesh interactions occur. Figure 13 shows the impact of mesh phasing on the amplitudes of different resonances (varying ω1) for ρ=1/2 by numerical integration. The amplitude is dictated by |R3| in case 1 (ωl=ωa/z) of equation (26). The phase angle (2πς2-πς1-2φ) controls the interaction of the two mesh stiffness variations. By tuning the mesh phasing φ, one can reduce or increase the amplitude of certain resonances. The waterfall plot of dynamic response y2 shows that the mesh phasing has different impact on different resonances. For the example system, the amplitude of mode 1 is minimized at φ=0.75π (v11v21<0 and cos(2πς2-πς1-2φ)=1) while the amplitude of mode 2 is maximized at φ=0.75π (v12v22>0). Figure 13.
Impact of mesh phasing on the amplitude of response from numerical integration for ρ = 1/2, ɛ1=ɛ2 = 0.3, ς1=1.7, ς2 = 1.6, and ζ = 3%.

On the other hand, the two meshes do not interact with each other for case 2 (ωl=zωa,z>2or ρ≠z,1/z) in equations (26) and (27). For example, mesh phasing (non-dimensionlized by 2π) has no effect on the dynamic response for the example system with ρ=3/5.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Asymptotic solutions for the frequency response of two-stage counter-shaft gear systems are found by the method of multiple scales. The perturbation solutions agree well with numerical integration and a semi-analytical harmonic balance method at fundamental, subharmonic and second harmonic resonances for a range of system parameters. The primary observations are
The analytical closed-form expressions from the method of multiple scales capture the nonlinear characteristics (peak amplitude, contact loss initiation, softening, and stability) and connect the physical parameters to these features.
Whether two mesh excitations jointly drive a resonance depends strongly on the ratio of the two mesh frequencies. The ratio determines whether strong or weak mesh interactions occur. When this ratio is an integer or its reciprocal significant mesh interactions occur between the two meshes and their fluctuating mesh stiffnesses. Smaller integers generally lead to stronger mesh interactions than bigger integers. The interaction can reduce or increase amplitude depending on the parameters and the resonance under consideration. The analytical expressions show the various effects. By tuning parameters such as mesh phasing, contact ratio, mesh stiffness fluctuations, and vibration modes, mesh cancellation can be achieved on the resonances of most concern.
When the mesh frequency ratio is not an integer or its reciprocal, there are minimal interactions between the two meshes. Nevertheless, the system cannot be treated as two single mesh gear pairs because response in a particular mode drives all system degrees of freedom, in general. While a non-integer ratio reduces the number of possible resonant conditions, it also prevents use of strategies that beneficially use mesh interaction to reduce vibration.
When mesh interaction occurs, mesh phasing can significantly change whether the interaction between the two meshes reduces or increases vibration through constructive or destructive interaction. For fundamental resonances this impact is different for different modes, but it is invariant for subharmonic resonances.
For subharmonic resonance, the instability interval width correlates well with the peak amplitude and can be used as a design quantity to minimize vibration. The linear period-2 solutions have discontinuous frequency response curves (jump phenomena) without mesh interactions. These change to steep but continuous frequency response curves with mesh interactions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: number of teeth and mass of each gear
rotational degree of freedom of each gear
mesh stiffness (j is the mesh index)
torsional stiffness of the middle shaft
right-hand side excitation term of the governing equation
tooth separation function and its harmonics
the mean values of kj, K, and xj
the peak-peak amplitudes of the mesh stiffnesses and their dimensionless quantities
ratio of two mesh stiffness fluctuations

tooth separation time interval and tooth separation angle
ratio of two average mesh stiffnesses
dimensionless quantities including parametric excitation and tooth separation
the discrete Fourier expansions of mass, damping matrix, and load vector
the discretization of the mesh stiffness matrix
discretized mesh stiffness vectors and its Fourier coefficients

sec.p: Substitution of equation (12) into the right-hand side of equation (11) yields the solvability conditions to prevent secular terms causing unbounded, aperiodic response (34) (35) where only the first harmonic of ka is retained. While equation (34) is nonlinear because the H∧1,2 depend on Ad, Ad=0 is an asymptotically stable fixed point of the linearized and nonlinear equation (34). The steady-state (α'=β'=0) response of equation (35) yields As≠0. Thus, the dynamic response is confined to the sth mode us.

With the substitution As=α(τ1)expiβ(τ1), y=Vu, and equation (12), the first-order solutions for the dynamic transmission error are (36) where γ=στ1-β is the response phase and α and β are as yet undetermined constants. Vanishing of the dynamic transmission error delineates tooth contact and tooth separation. Thus, the conditions yj=0 define the period of tooth separation, and these yield the separation angles as (37)

yj and H∧j are in-phase and have the same frequency, so the periodic H∧j in equation (6) are expanded as (38) (39) where the Fourier coefficients h0, g0, hn and gn are O(1) and depend implicitly on the amplitude α.

Substitution of equations (38) and (39) into equation (35) for steady response (α'=γ'=0) yields the conditions (40) where Θ is the phase angle of the complex κj1 in equation (4). After eliminating γ+Θ from equation (40) and using ωa=cs+ɛσ and μ=2ζ/ɛ, equation (13) is obtained.
